text.eng: V.— THE EQUIPMENT OF PERSIAN SOLDIERS

text.lat: 15.— Persae hoc modo instructi sunt. In capite pileos gestant; hos tiaras vocant: circa corpus, tunicas manicatas varii coloris, et loricas ferreis squamis in piscium similitudinem: circa crura, braccas: pro clipeis vero, crates vimineas. A tergo suspensas habent pharetras: hastae breves sunt, arcus vero grandes, tela ex arundine: praeterea ad dextrum femur e zona suspensus est pugio.
text.eng: 15.— The Persians are equipped in this manner. On their head they wear caps; these they call tiaras: around the body, sleeved tunics of various colors, and breastplates with iron scales resembling fish: around the legs, trousers: instead of shields, wickerwork. On the back they have quivers suspended: the spears are short, the bows indeed large, weapons made of reed: moreover, a dagger is suspended from the belt on the right thigh.
